E4C3CAA92AEA438AAB3CAD8A1E2DBCFA.description: appreciate Aboriginal philosophy, spirituality and love of land and nature.

F1D8611E50AA47D98DCF5FCFC370A12B.description:
compare how Aboriginal oral tradition connects the expression of personal, spiritual, social and
cultural aspects of that individual within the group

E42FE26C62A04B7386F449D38358E3BB.description:
develop an understanding that Aboriginal art reflects the belief that art is holistic in nature and is
integrated in all aspects of Aboriginal life

3BA46FD1468E475296CAA5572CB95315.description: compare similarities and differences in expressions of environmental relationships

060C4D3757184985BFECDE69AF9945C0.description:
describe the relationship of environment expressed in the art form, oral tradition and literature of

33B2DE5E8C9A42B29DEE3BBFADD155AA.description: identify and appreciate the diversity of cultural expression of Aboriginal peoples

A282A90E4DCE4D51BA0889E3E2744B8C.description: develop an understanding of many Aboriginal art forms, oral tradition and literature:

930598C559C04B2392F759D4905874DB.description:
identify the different Aboriginal authors and how they use different methods in portraying their
experiences. Select two Aboriginal authors; e.g., Maria Campbell, Verna Kirkness, Gail Bear:
– explore the life experiences of Aboriginal authors and determine how they influenced what
they wrote about
– identify and evaluate the methods each author uses to bring the message to the reader
– relate to how the authors portrayed the human experience through their writings
– discuss how the authors’ beliefs and values influenced their writings
– examine the purpose that each author had in mind

604921F7530846B5A144D524A34EA73C.description:
identify how Aboriginal writers use symbolism, allusions and inference to portray their messages
to the reader

6960476BA5C04F0591798973C9AB9D18.description: examine the contributions made by Aboriginal authors

385DCD8A6B454AD6A37DC598B2645420.description: explore the lives, experiences and values of Aboriginal authors through their writings

9026D1826B834D39B1AE0F8ADD1E6479.description: interpret and recognize significant oral symbolism and expressions:

D65A7962F63A4791B03A240CB2433E19.description:
respond to and appreciate the importance of the oral tradition in the education and socialization
processes

B52CAADF4BD24BA28CE4ED8A03774A90.description: explain how oral tradition, legends, humour and stories assist in the transmission of culture

061CA6C1D3A945D5A7051FAFB077AC68.description: describe the central role and function of the oral tradition as a means of cultural transmission

73F3B9B1480A49F5BD4DECBA2C3027F1.description: appreciate how oral traditions influence ideas, perspectives and interpretations:

85E6352FA5B84508ACE9D00EA866E32B.description: Students will demonstrate an understanding of Aboriginal art forms, oral tradition and literature

B695FC9067344687A17CA78AF9D93EF5.description: appreciate the role of Aboriginal involvement in Alberta political and economic organizations

FD453122AC644C7781EB2524143D0FE7.description:
describe Aboriginal peoples organizations as to their mandates in:
– improving the quality of life
– self-government
– economic development
– protection of treaties

4A4C8D69D9DE4C9EBECF7AC2DA521922.description: First Nations: Assembly of First Nations (AFN), Tribal Councils (6, 7, 8, Independent)

7D402345D06F4573AC3FE34072A9B14B.description:
demonstrate an understanding of why Aboriginal peoples of Canada have formed unique
organizations and alliances to deal with the federal and/or provincial governments:

5620A8A74CE74D0EB60786EB49D64A63.description: appreciate how leaders are striving to strengthen Aboriginal peoples economically and politically

24A3E2D79DB741A7B80F54C3A2849219.description:
• describe and analyze Aboriginal political and economic issues, including:
– poverty
– economic instability
– land cooperatives; e.g., in 1800s, small groups of Iroquois and voyageurs were brought from
the east to work in trading companies—they settled in the Jasper and Grande Cache areas,
intermarried with the Cree, and set up land cooperatives

783AE0C7D5B4401AAB3E5592949B5421.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the current issues being addressed by Aboriginal political and
economic organizations:

D848BE4478D54FA38722F64A1DE790AF.description:
research and describe how Aboriginal peoples have successfully contributed in the provincial,
national and international marketplace

EE269107995645D7B698949435ACEC52.description:
analyze and evaluate how oil, gas and lumber entrepreneurships have changed the quality of life in
Alberta Aboriginal communities

DD7036B069C84D69AA2D7F2ECE759F0F.description:
demonstrate an understanding that many Aboriginal peoples have successfully entered into the world
of business to improve their quality of life while keeping in balance traditional practices:

29C3A53E34A146FE8BA5456B20CC1E0B.description: appreciate and respect contributions of the Buffalo Jump

9A3E6EB5018C42E292310D3D6BE9A61D.description: appreciate the contribution of Aboriginal peoples as fur traders and entrepreneurs of the West

7CADA4D14B0E4B54823C8D590D1EDBD7.description: evaluate the effects on Aboriginal peoples as the fur trade declined

40321D3617184C089263C640530B63F4.description: describe the roles of Aboriginal peoples in the Canadian fur trade—beaver, seal, buffalo

86F8497E5FA642CD910A69E94715734C.description: demonstrate an understanding of the contributions of Aboriginal peoples to the historical trade:

3A21224D9614493284F87A8ADD56AA76.description:
compare economic and political structures of two groups; e.g., hereditary chiefs, band and tribal
customs and Indian Act chief, Chiefs’ committee on economic development

77DFCDA2C7EF438691408D28CBF5624C.description: research and report on the influences of Europeans and Aboriginal peoples on each other

40EB98F0290D403B9F3BDDDFA4907B45.description:
demonstrate an understanding of how the interaction of two cultural groups has resulted in political
and economic adaptation and/or interdependence:

DAB5301FC79D4D99A9FD455985355CB0.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the historical, political and economic organizations of the First
Nations, Métis and Inuit people

8B469C9C59754D4F99E0350CBC23D799.description:
Students will demonstrate an understanding of the political and economic organization of Aboriginal
peoples.

8DE39483FA714E88BC667AF7B648E436.description:
demonstrate an understanding that after European contact, many Aboriginal peoples incorporated
Christianity into their lifestyles.

AC14718487C24807BD3CC85356A1F9C4.description:
describe the general role and significance of non-sacred aspects of ceremonies by Aboriginal
peoples; e.g., round dance, tea dance, powwows

B435D7101D08479E89B0E6239592D4A0.description: appreciate and respect that Aboriginal peoples have ceremonies to express their spiritual nature

C97AE43DFF4B48DABD6057A1513BD7E1.description: demonstrate an understanding that ceremonies have strong spiritual and social significance:

appreciate and respect that Aboriginal peoples traditionally view life and its interrelated parts as a
never-ending cycle

DBC00C556970402A8F540D3E81DD5453.description:
research the significance of the following symbols:
– the Circle2
– Medicine Wheel

72B1E1E9B7AE47D6B976DFEC11603973.description: demonstrate an understanding that cycle of life is fundamental to the Aboriginal way of life:

F7D76711DD0E4C78AD7A232C162AEBD7.description:
appreciate and respect the diversity of oral traditions of Aboriginal peoples that provides the
foundation for Aboriginal worldviews and spirituality

BFC9EB82FB03453790B551B61D5062CA.description: examine the role of creation stories and legends in the lives of Aboriginal peoples in Canada

E7E7B01A4CE0452EAADCC9BF391757EF.description:
examine traditional Aboriginal stories on creation that have inspirational messages about young
people recognizing their gifts, journeying to take on challenges and accomplishing feats to help
others

198EB224DCFB4F788D6E13F74A3A939C.description:
demonstrate an understanding that Aboriginal stories on creation of the world and Aboriginal peoples
provide a strong spiritual foundation:

9A3B1AA3091F4151BA2F1E18445EDA2B.description:
appreciate and respect the diversity of traditional spiritual beliefs and practices of Aboriginal
peoples

6DA9B57535694DE09F07D31CDF545CBB.description: appreciate and respect the value of Elders in helping people discover their inner gifts and strengths

0C54ED24EE1F4EEC9421A9661D904ACD.description:
research the following aspects of spirituality by; e.g., interviewing a local Elder regarding:
interrelationship of animate and inanimate, harmony, unity, sharing and generosity, protocols and
accepted traditional practices

74DB8EB1045748CB9D254CDA3A312385.description: analyze the role of sharing and generosity in traditional Aboriginal cultures

5ABB82A9170B4CAA905EED4AEDA8945A.description: examine why living in harmony and unity is essential to traditional Aboriginal cultures

D0D514DCF7554743A1A53A437D8B301A.description: examine how animate and inanimate objects are interrelated and respected in Aboriginal cultures

666644A815A34BB5B37577157C5E502B.description: Students will demonstrate an understanding of aspects of Aboriginal spirituality and worldviews

92C99820074E4DA58BAC1950DC490203.description:
research, identify and describe the development of Métis communities, including Métis
settlements in Alberta

40687090007C43D5821F0039D3EF857D.description:
recognize that the Métis advanced by adapting along with European technology and forming a new

C618FFE5B2CC4DE3A4930820913CD05B.description:
investigate the origin of the Métis family, and describe similarities and differences between Métis
and First Nations families

7FFEB4114822483FA1845DDFBAD8C0ED.description: research the fur trade as an essential, mutual support for Aboriginal peoples

5DEB6593B04A4E9C8D1B224524A05E66.description: appreciate mutual support between Aboriginal peoples and colonial governance

7F9FB941957A4923BF7640025B812204.description:
identify and explain how Aboriginal peoples shared resources with fur traders, explorers,

68EB309458DF4DFF8BE441776C5C68A3.description:
demonstrate an understanding that the Métis family unit gave rise to what is now known as the Métis
people:

164C4B90361741F1ADD18972B79E1148.description: analyze that economic prosperity came through trade and early European contact

43534BB0A6284CAE884EEFB7D6EC9B32.description:
research traditional Aboriginal governance and characteristics of organization; e.g., clans, families,
bands, leaders/chiefs, councils of leaders/chiefs, leader/chief of council

55382F4717334D2686A8262106C13D1A.description:
demonstrate an understanding that, historically, Aboriginal peoples were sovereign nations and
Europeans and Aboriginal nations coexisted in a state of mutual recognition of sovereign status with
mutual economic benefits from trades

5BFBF80B94364D4C9826F89359B04AF1.description:
appreciate that the traditional concepts and practices of mutual support and conflict resolution have

DAE47222EF544AB2BA5E4989027A1508.description: appreciate that Aboriginal peoples’ practice of mutual support was essential for survival

F2A3C42F14EB4877BF5DC36DFFB8546A.description: demonstrate an understanding that mutual support connected various Aboriginal peoples:

EDF2EA1E8751412CB71F4B8185DF1BBC.description:
interpret, historically, that circular seasonal time frames were a major influence for moving from
place to place

DBC2CFE1F49C41FCA360A7FE67B5E707.description:
research how the geographical regions influenced Aboriginal culture by examining the following:
– behaviours/restrictions influenced by geographical factors
– harmony with land, clans, families
– spiritual forces in nature/interconnectedness
– sharing of resources
– plants and animals

C036D2508410424CBB506F7C62718A2F.description:
research and trace settlement and migration patterns from a historical perspective, and describe

2B6D4353D9054733AC19DFB204AC3CAA.description:
compare and contrast the main geographical regions of Canada, and examine how development of
different Aboriginal cultures was influenced by various factors

8227753E5FFF43ED9834C573B4618D6F.description:
recognize and demonstrate an understanding that Aboriginal peoples moved from place to place
according to well-defined patterns:

0C783A5E00364A06B6D44E2A6413B96F.description:
appreciate that Aboriginal peoples shared many of the same characteristics and values; e.g.,
respect for nature, harmony with the land

FDA0A9336DF642B095BF1F568FE3534B.description: interpret Canada as being culturally diverse before the arrival of the Europeans

DC88D11F1F16422C813BC8BC99B9C398.description: identify and locate the major linguistic and cultural groups in Alberta and Canada

ED776C111CA743A593D6CEF057E194A4.description:
demonstrate an understanding that Aboriginal peoples developed distinct cultures in differing
Canadian environments:

3E8AB020F7C643D8A8E07F99556B77D5.description:
appreciate that Aboriginal peoples used sign language to communicate with each other and to

5B8BD1E89C34487887784F2771BB5BCD.description:
distinguish between legends and stories of many diverse linguistic and cultural groups in Alberta

08431328CE3948789BF8B8B874ABF447.description:
appreciate the role of legends and stories of how Aboriginal peoples are interconnected to the land

5D3A7969310C493C8D5D6B6744456268.description:
demonstrate an understanding that there are distinctive narrations of legends and stories that are
related to cultural characteristics of Aboriginal peoples:

B92DDCAEFAF341619FAAC33C45C742C0.description:
examine oral cultural origins and settlement theory; e.g., research and compare Aboriginal
Creation to one or both of the following: Beringia theory, Polynesian theory

57372D85C96A4BF5B06F58E0BF48453B.description: identify cultural characteristics to geographical features occupied by the first people on land

EAA63CCD50204CFB81FA54B644299573.description: demonstrate an awareness that creation stories reflect spiritual connections to the land

D7767BF651A64C42B4676110400415B1.description:
appreciate that many Aboriginal peoples identify with creation stories that introduce place and

78D4ED4529144808B3B7B5D9329061CE.description:
demonstrate an understanding of different perspectives to the origin and settlement of Aboriginal
peoples in North America:

06F2B357E6924D86B59F6C9CD15BE7A7.description:
Students will demonstrate an understanding of the diverse cultural characteristics, origins, and migration
